abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Hungary Power Project. The main
            objective was originally intended to: (a) increase
            utilization of domestic coal in primary energy generation in
            accordance with Government policy at that time; (b)
            reconstruct and rehabilitate 8 coal power stations belonging
            to Hungarian Power Companies Limited (MVM) and upgrade other
            MVM power stations, transmission and distribution systems;
            and (c) improve MVM 's operational efficiency and
            management. Bank performance can be considered satisfactory.
            The performance of the Borrower was also satisfactory. The
            key lessons learned in the project were: (i) more attention
            should have been given at appraisal to cost comparisons
            between indigenous coal and alternative energy options,
            including environmental costs; (ii) it is important to take
            account of the risks of actual demand turning out to be
            different from forecasts, and to adjust investment programs
            promptly to changed demand information; (iii) to avoid
            procurement delays under international competitive bidding
            the Bank should provide to new borrowers and beneficiaries
            detailed information on its procurement guidelines during
            project preparation; and (iv) financial covenants should be
            flexible enough to ensure financial soundness of the
            enterprises through periods of falling as well as increasing demand.
